description: Operational metrics to indicate Management Plane Controller (MPC) health.

panels.description:
How long does it take to execute the GetAllConfigObjects grpc method to retrieve all the configuration objects.
If you want to know the error cause take a look at the grpc charts that contain the status response codes.
panels.title: Get All Config Objects duration

panels.description:
The number of resources that sent from TSB to MPC.

This metric shows the number of objects that are created, updated, and deleted as part of a configuration push from MPC to XCP.

This metric can be used together with the XCP push operations and push duration to get an understanding of how the amount of resources being pushed to XCP affects the time it takes for the entire configuration push operation to complete.
panels.title: Received configs

panels.description: Time it takes to process an entire config set. It shows the details about the amount of time spent pre-processing the configurations, converting them to XCP, and pushing them to the k8s cluster
panels.title: Config Processing duration

panels.description: Configuration updates received from TSB are processed by MPC and translated into XCP resources. This metric shows the number of objects of each type MPC will convert.
panels.title: Received configs by type

panels.description: Time it takes to convert TSB resources to the XCP APIs.
panels.title: Total Conversion Time by Type every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Time it takes to convert TSB resources to the XCP APIs.
panels.title: Conversion Time by Type every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Conversions by resource executed in a time period. This can be used to understand the throughput of the MPC conversions.
panels.title: Conversions by Resource every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Conversions Invalidations by resource executed in a time period. This can be used to understand the throughput of the MPC conversions.
panels.title: Conversions Invalidations by Resource every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Time it takes to invalidate TSB resources for a given conversion to the XCP APIs.
panels.title: Conversion Invalidation Time every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Configuration and onboarded cluster messages received from TSB.

The number of update messages may increase or decrease based on the time it takes for MPC to fully process the messages. The more time it takes to process, the less frequent config updates will be retrieved.
panels.title: Updates from TSB every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of resources that are pushed to XCP.

This metric shows the number of objects that are created, updated, and deleted as part of a configuration push from MPC to XCP.
It also shows how many fetch calls to the k8s api server are done.

This metric can be used together with the TSB tp MPC sent configs and XCP push operations and push duration to get an understanding of how the amount of resources being pushed to XCP affects the time it takes for the entire configuration push operation to complete.
panels.title: MPC to XCP pushed configs

panels.description:
The number of resources that failed while pushing to XCP.

This metric shows the number of objects that fail when they are tried to be created, updated, and deleted as part of a configuration push from MPC to XCP.
It also shows the number of failed fetch calls to the k8s api server.

This metric can be used together with the MPC to TSB push configs and the XCP push operations and push duration to get an understanding of how the amount of resources being pushed to XCP affects the time it takes for the entire configuration push operation to complete.
panels.title: MCP to XCP pushed configs error

panels.description:
Config Status update messages sent over the gRPC streams, from XCP to MPC to XCP.

This metric can help understand how messages are queued in TSB when it is under load. The value for both metrics should always be the same. If the Received by TSB metric has a value lower than the MPC one, it means TSB is under load and cannot process all messages sent by MPC as fast as MPC is sending them.
panels.title: Config Status updates every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
This is the number of config status updates that are processed by the Management Plane Controller (MPC), that are received from XCP and to be sent to TSB.

There are two gRPC streams, one that connects XCP to MPC and another one that connects MPC to TSB.
panels.title: Config Status updates processed every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of connection (and reconnection) attempts on the config status updates streams.
MPC sends the config status updates over a permanently connected gRPC stream to TSB. At the same time, XCP sends them to MPC. This metric shows the number of connections and reconnections that happened on each stream.
panels.title: Config Status stream connection attempts every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Number of config status reports handled by TSB.
Each received config status report is either handled or skipped.
- Handled: Process and store the status report directly, or if --max-status-report-workers is > 1, enqueued for async processing.
- Skipped: For duplicated status reports.
panels.title: TSB Handled Status Reports $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Number of operations done in the config status cache when receiving new config statuses.
panels.title: Config status cache operations every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of config status reports processed by TSB.
This number must be the same as the number of handled ones without the skipped ones.
panels.title: TSB Processed Status Reports in $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The P99 duration in milliseconds of  handling a received status reports handled by TSB.
Each received config status report is either handled or skipped.
- Handled: Process and store the status report directly, or if --max-status-report-workers is > 1, enqueued for async processing.
- Skipped: For duplicated status reports.
panels.title: TSB Handling Status Reports Duration $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Number of operations done in the cache by event type.

This metric helps understand the amount of event processing that can be skipped on the TSB side when receiving events because TSB already knows about them, and help understand how status event reporting relates to load on the TSB side.
panels.title: Config status cache operations by event type every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The P99 duration in milliseconds of  processing config status reports handled by TSB.
Processing of a config status report involves analyse, apply/storing the result, propagate to parents and dependants.
panels.title: TSB Processing Status Reports Duration $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
Distribution of the status report work across the different shards.
panels.title: Status Reports Work per Shard Distribution

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
Amount of status processing jobs processed
panels.title: Work executions every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
Time it takes for workers to process a single status update event.
panels.title: Status updates worker time every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
The P99 delay is milliseconds since a config status report started the enqueuing until the queue accepted(enqueued) the config status report.

If the P99 delay goes high it means that that a shard of the queue is filled up reaching its max capacity.
If it goes over minutes, it means that there is deadlock probably.
panels.title: TSB Status Updates Enqueue Delay $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
The delay is milliseconds since a config status report started the enqueuing until the queue accepted(enqueued) the config status report.

The config status report queue has a fixed size of element in can't hold per bucket. 
If the enqueuing latency goes up, it means that there is contention in the queue and more elements cannot be placed until the queue releases spaces by consuming its enqueued elements.
panels.title: TSB Status Updates Enqueue Delay $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
The delay is milliseconds since a config status report is received and processed by the work queue.
panels.title: TSB Status Updates Worker Delay $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
Only applies when tsb --max-status-report-workers is > 1.
The delay is milliseconds since a config status report is received and processed by the work queue.
panels.title: TSB Status Updates Worker Delay $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description: Cluster status update messages received from XCP over a gRPC stream.
panels.title: Cluster Status Update from XCP every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of cluster status updates received by the Management Plane Controller (MPC) from XCP that must be processed and sent to TSB.

XCP sends the cluster status updates (e.g. services deployed in the cluster) over a permanently connected gRPC stream to MPC. This metric shows the number of messages received and processed by MPC on that stream.
panels.title: Cluster updates from XCP  processed every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
This is the number of cluster status updates that are processed by the Management Plane Controller (MPC) to be sent to TSB.

MPC sends the cluster status updates over a gRPC stream that is permanently connected to TSB, and this metric shows the number of cluster updates that are processed by MPC and sent to TSB on that stream.
panels.title: XCP cluster status updates Sent to TSB every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of connection (and reconnection) attempts on the cluster status updates stream.
MPC sends the cluster status updates over a permanently connected gRPC stream to TSB. This metric shows the number of connections and reconnections that happened on that stream.
panels.title: Cluster status updates to TSB stream connection attempts every $mpcTimePeriod

panels.description:
The number of connection (and reconnection) attempts on the cluster status updates from XCP stream.
XCP sends the cluster status updates over a permanently connected gRPC stream to MPC. This metric shows the number of connections and reconnections that happened on that stream.
panels.title: Cluster updates from XCP stream connection attempts every $mpcTimePeriod
GC Count by Component in Management Plane
GC Duration by Component in Management Plane
Heap Allocations by Component in Management Plane
Heap Objects by Component in Management Plane

panels.description: The heap memory size during the next GC cycle. GC is used to guarantee that the value is no less than the value of
panels.title: Next GC Target by Component in Management Plane
Heap Utilization Percentage  by Component in Management Plane
GC CPU Fraction  by Component in Management Plane
Goroutines  by Component in Management Plane
Heap Sys by Component in Management Plane

panels.description: The rate of RPCs started on the server.
panels.title: gRPC Server Calls Started Rate

panels.description: The rate of RPCs completed on the server.
panels.title: gRPC Server Handled Rate

panels.description: The rate of the RPCs started on the client.
panels.title: gRPC Client Calls Started Rate

panels.description: The rate of RPCs completed on the client.
panels.title: gRPC Client Handled Rate

title: MPC Operational Status
